 Originally posted on August 21, 2009 Unreal Tournament 3 was an easy purchase after the incredible UT2004, at least for me. It promised more of the same awesome gameplay with a brand new engine that looks gorgeous. For the most part, UT3 lives up to the brand name, despite some minor quibbles.Visually speaking, the game is phenomenal, with an engine that may not be so new as of 2009, but still looks absolutely great. it really shines in UT3's very meticulously crafted beautiful maps, which is where you can see the full potential of the engine. The lighting and particle effects especially are very pretty, from and artistic standpoint, and they stay true to UT's unique art design and feel. I have no complaints on this front.The sound effects in the game are for the most part quite good, with the timeless beacons of success like "monster kill!" and "dominating!" making a glorious return. The macho voice acting is of course completely over the top, but this is really to be expected, and as far as I'm concerned, it comes with the territory.The gameplay is good, for the most part. DM, TDM, CTF, and every combination of vehicles in battlefield style flag capping and vehicle CTF make an appearance, along with a few more bizarre game modes, and of course good old fashioned duel. There are a plethora of maps, character models, and mutators to suit your particular fancy, and the weapons look, sound, and feel really satisfying and true to the series, with the rocket launcher and flak cannon making particularly gruesome returns. Puzzling, however, is the lack of objective based attack and defend game modes like in UT2004, which saw sides attacking objectives and progressing ultimately towards a final target with a time limit, and then teams would switch sides and try to do better. But wait, you say, UT3 has exactly that in the form of warfare. This is technically true, but UT2004 had some very map specific objectives in very creative scenarios that as far as I can tell are missing from UT3. Where is the space station assault mission? or the tram attack? Oh well, minor quibbles, all in all the gameplay is quite good.As far as bang for your buck, UT3 is quite impressive, with 40 plus hours of gameplay at least, and theoretically much more. While the campaign isn't to interesting, these games have never been about single player, although the bots are quite adept if you choose that route. With the new Titan pack and the possibility of more free content, UT3 will last me a for a long time to come.I can heartily recommend it as a purchase well worth the investment to any fan of shooters, especially those from an older generation, or previous fans of the series.

-Quick Review-Unreal Tournament 3 is a First person shooter developed by Epic Games, Inc. and released in 2007. I'm not sure what else I should include in my Quick Review Section... There's tons of content, the single player is pretty solid, there are still plenty of servers with small clusters of people playing multi-player, and getting Co-Op to work over steam was a pain in the butt (we used Hamachi).-Detailed breakdown review-Just a heads up:This is the first Unreal Tournament Game I've ever played. Once I beat the game, and then re watched all the cutsenes I realized I had NO idea why the game was called "Unreal Tournament". There was no Tournament, there wasn't anything unreal about it, unless we're talking about respawning...For those in the dark about it, earlier Unreal Tournament games actually did take place in a tournament. The "Unreal" part of the name is probably because the whole Unreal franchise uses the Unreal Game Engine.Oh wait, I get it, the main driving feature for this game is area-shooting (I normally think of the Campaign as the primary selling factor), so there we go, mystery solved while writing this review. I feel silly.


Footage from a cut-scene in Unreal Tournament 3. 
A Screenshot of Unreal Tournament 3: Black Edition
By: Atratzu




Story: There are 5 factions in Unreal Tournament 3: Iron Guard (mercenaries), The Ronin (which is the faction you are part of in the story, you may play as the others in multiplayer though. The Ronin are survivors from a Krall attack), The Krall (I like to think of them as Orcs and Orgres, so naturally I would prefer to be playing as them), The Liandri (Basically Robots), and lastly the Necris (sounds like Necromancer? Basically they're the Borg, or undead. They're pretty Metal.)In all honesty I barely noticed the difference between Humanoids and factions, Red is Dead in my book. The most distinct Faction was the Krall, and I don't feel like I really fought against them all that much. (which is odd... seeing as they massacred the Ronin's Village...?)The story is made up of 5 Acts, each Act starts out with a Cut scene, and before you jump into a mission you're given a short description or background for why you're attacking and what your mission is.Oh, by the way the protagonist's name is "Reaper", whom is not nearly as Edge lord as we're used to from Overwatch, but as far as deep voiced rough protagonists go, he's pretty standard.Incase this is spoiler territory for people:Act 1) The Ronin's Village is sacked by the Krall, the Ronin hook up with the Iron Guard and they all go to war against the Axon. Wait, who are the Axon? I'm glad you asked, they're apparently not an offical faction, they're the primary vehicle developers and the Iron Guards leader "Malcolm" is an idiot (actually he's an opportunist, but the game paints him as a fool)Act 2, 3, and 4 just kind of blurr together as "more the same" Act 5 is when stuff gets serious and the Ronin are like "Screw this, we're going to go fight the Necris Lady who attacked our village our self". And I won't risk saying anything more in detail on that, because THAT would be way more spoilery then I do.All-in-all, the campaign felt like playing a bunch of different online pvp games but with bots, all strung together with dialogue before playing the mission and every 10 missions a cut scene.Gameplay: The Gameplay is where Unreal tournament 3: Black Edition Shines! First... The core of every FPS: Which kinds of guns do you get?1) A hammer gun you will probably never use again, 2) a pistol you only use if you're out of ammo or respawned, 3) a poison bio weapon which leaves green death bubles on the ground walls and ceiling, 4) a Laser rifle which I don't think has a distance limit, 5) Your standard "rifle" type gun, it fires a lot of little energy bullets at a typical rate (visible and dodge-able however!), 6) Good 'ol Gatling gun, 7) Shot gun, careful with this one kids, the bullets ricochet and I have killed myself with it more times then I'd care to admit, 8) Rocket Launcher (it's death. highest damage, moderate speed rockets, splash damage, or nail 'em in the rib cage to watch 'em explode), 9) Sniper rifle.There are a number of special weapons you can pick up and find, and in multiplayer games they may even mod the weapons to behave differently, but generally speaking the aforementioned guns are your standard staple in the campaign.I should also mention that some weapons have an alternative shot by clicking the right mouse button, the one that sticks out in my mind is the rocket launcher will charge up 3 rockets and fire them at once, and the shot gun fires a round shot which explodes into tons of smaller shots.)Next Vehicles... I'm not going to list them, but there are a lot of them, each has a pretty unique feel to it, getting used to controlling them takes some time, especially Necris vehicles (Two vehicle manufacturers: Axon, and Necris)There are 3 options on the main menu if you want to jump into the game. Campaign, Instant Action, and Multiplayer. Campaign is for the "story", Instant Action is for offline play, and Multiplayer is for online play.


Pro-tip to anyone starting: The + in the bottom right is your health, the object on the ground is a health kit. - I wish I had known earlier 
A Screenshot of Unreal Tournament 3: Black Edition
By: Atratzu




Health pickups, power ups, Armor, jump boosters, and more!Game types: Deathmatch (Free for all), Team Death match (Industry Standard), Capture the Flag (Same as when we were kids, only with guns), Vehicle CTF (Same as normal CTF except you can run your friends over), Warfare (A long game of capture the control point, ended by blowing up the core in the enemy's base), Greed (Kill people, pick up skulls, try to reach it to the enemy spawn room to score), Betrayal (really really REALLY weird, you kill enemies until you're assigned to a team, then you right click to fire off a blue shot which will kill people on your team, then you hide and you keep your score), Duel (1v1 me bro).


I joined this server which played "I Believe In Father Christmas" by Greg Lake on loop. Very festive, until the 10th loop. haha 
A Screenshot of Unreal Tournament 3: Black Edition
By: Atratzu




There are a total of 60 maps... SIXTY! That's crazy.Conclusion: I must be getting long winded in my old age, I didn't think I had this much to say about Unreal Tournament 3: Black Edition. I had a lot of fun playing it, I don't think I'll be sticking around with it much longer though... the achievements are a bit too tedious for my tastes and there are other games to review!Someday down the line I might come back to this game, but as far as FPS's Go, this one is pretty good. You could definitely sink a fair amount of time into the game if you're looking to experience the whole game.The fact that there are still a lot of servers up is a good sign. (At least there was a whole page of them around 1900 CST, with most of them having people in them!)Thank you for taking the time to read my review, Atratzu signing off.

												Unreal Tournament 3 is another great UT game. Graphics and sounds are amazing as always, gameplay is quick and engaging, there are a lot of interesting and varied weapons, vehicles and maps. However, when compared to the older games in the series it doesn't seem to be the best. When it comes to Warfare/Onslaught (same mode, differently called in UT3 and UT2004), then UT2004 seems to be the best as the gameplay is better thought-through and generally maps seem to be better too. It also feels like the developers went too far with vehicles in this mode in UT3, and in consequence there is just too many kinds of them where some don't even seem very useful. When it comes to Deathmatch/Team Deathmatch or Capture the Flag, then the first Unreal Tournament still remains the best up to this day, in my opinion. It has the most solid gameplay in DM/TDM/CtF and no other game in the series ever came close to it. Do I recommend UT3? Sure, it's a great game in itself, however, even more I would recommend the first UT or UT2004 (depending on what game modes you want to play). Still, even if you own the older games in the series you still might want to get UT3 on a sale just to check it out, at least to play on some different maps than you usually do.

												I bought a boxed copy of this game from Amazon on the day it was released around 9 years ago. Since then I've played literally thousands of hours of UT3 and have just over 4 million kills to my name. For sure there are better UT players than me out there, but few have as much experience.In many ways UT3 was and is the purest on-line 'traditional' (i.e. not a military game like Battlefield or ARMA) FPS experience ever brought to the PC. The graphics, sound and general game play still look good today and hold up relatively well against the likes of the recently released Doom and other such games.UT3 features a decent number of game modes, a good pile of maps and all your favourite staple Unreal weapons, some of which date all the way back to the original Unreal circa 1998. All in all plenty of content to play with. All that being said I find it difficult to recommend this game. Why? Since GameSpy closed their doors the on-line community has collapsed and it's now nearly impossible to find and take part in anything other than LAN games.The second issue is that due to the age of the game, the nearly limitless number of mods, maps and mutators that were common and easily available for UT3 are now becoming very difficult to find as various hosting sites have long since gone off-line.I'd absolutely recommend this game for solo play as the AI is decent and there's even a passable single player campaign. If however you purchase UT3 thinking you'll easily be able to jump in to on-line games you'll be in for an unpleasant shock as this has now become nearly impossible.So a guarded recommendation. If you enjoyed past UT games and somehow missed out on UT3, or if you had a non-steam version and want to add it to your collection then I'd unhesitatingly recommend it as it's so much fun. As a pure on-line experience (there really isn't one any more) it's difficult to recommend by now.For anyone who doesn't know, there is now a free to play UT4 available directly from Epic Games, though personally I dislike it intensely as they've completely borked the weapons balance, but that's another discussion for another time...

												This game is one of the best multiplayer shooters ever made (besides UT2004 of course). UT3 is very fast paced compared to other first person shooters. Players have the ability to dodge and wall dodge in order to move even more faster & to avoid being hit by enemies. Players don't have to worry about reloading their weapon either. I personally love the mods though since it makes the experience more worthwhile with better weapons & being able to level up weapon damage and health. Game type- I appreciate Greed which makes UT3 different from other Unreal games in a way. It may be said that Greed is similar to Bombing Run due to the "hoop" that one has to go through in order to score but they obviously aren't the exact same. In Greed, there are two teams (red and blue), the objective is to capture as many skulls as possible by killing enemies and score them at the enemy base. Even though not many people play anymore this will still be one of my favorites and I will keep going back to it just for fun. I really can't stop playing because it brings back good memories with my old clan members and the game nights we use to have every few weekends. Some of the best people I ever met were from UT! 												It's a fun first person shooter. Lots of weapons, vehicles, gametypes, and maps will keep you busy for a long time.Unfortunately, as the game came out in 2007 there isn't much of a multiplayer community left.The single player game pits you against bots. One of the main complaints about previous Unreal Tournament games is that there was basically no story or plot. So this time the developers came up with a plot complete with flashy cutscenes about how the Necris destroyed your colony and you're out for revenge. Some of it was a bit contrived -- Capture the Flag in a warzone? Yep, they have a technobabble explanation for it! But overall the addition of a storyline was appreciated and helped to elevate this game's single player mode over its predecessors.My main complaint about the bots is they have trouble with vehicle pathfinding sometimes. You'll see them stuck in traffic jams from time to time.And there's one mission in particular I should warn you about.  At the end of Chapter 2 there's a mission where the enemy team has a bunch of vehicles but you only have one. The catch is that one vehicle is a Leviathon, the most powerful vehicle in the game. The obvious idea is that you take the Leviathon and wreck the other team's vehicles.The execution of that idea fails because your bot teammates will hop into the Leviathon, which is the hardest to drive out of all the vehicles, and immediately get stuck inside your base. So not only do you not have your super vehicle, you don't have most of your team either, making this mission by far the hardest in the game (and it happens fairly early in the game too). I was eventually able to beat it by using my best card, which is like pre-mission buff you can earn.The game may have come out in 2007 but the graphics are still good by the standards of 2016. The music was unobtrusive and mostly forgettable.The gunplay is fantastic. The various mutators you can use with the maps add a lot of fun. For example, there's a "Titan" mutator that can make your character grow to the size of a giant if you're successful. This gives you extra health and firepower, but slows down your speed and possibly restricts you to certain areas of the map.In my opinion, this is the best game out of the Unreal Tournament series. If you like first person shooters you'll like Unreal Tournament 3.

												UT3 by Epic Games is the fourth game in the Unreal Tournament series and the eigth Unreal game. It runs on their Unreal 3 engine (hence the name) and it looks stunning. The gameplay is tight, the graphics are beautiful and the physics and particle (and gore) effects are amazing. Even though it's five years old the graphics can be tweaked to insane amounts and although it runs at a good framerate on my mid-range hardware if I were to max this baby out it would really push my system to the limits. If you're a fan of Unreal Tournament you'll probably enjoy this game for what it is but it does a few things differently than its predecessors that may annoy you. For one, UT3 focuses heavily on vehicle based combat. Now, I'm a big UT'99 fan and I felt it was possibly the most pure shooter experience I've ever had the joy of playing and it didn't need gimicks like fancy ships, hoverboards (seriously, you get a hoverboard to fly around on on bigger maps), and giant maps to be a great arena shooter. All you needed was running, and gunning. Now, that's not saying that UT3 lacks this, it certainly has smaller maps without hoverboards where you fly around and blast people to bloody bits just like the older games but it does have new mechanics you may like or dislike, such as the ability to "play dead" and fall down, which I found to be distracting, and a handy floating arrow that shows you where to go in CTF and Warfare modes (it's not obtrusive, trust me). The level design is also incredibly well done, with fun things to play with like different physics and rainfall and hazards and difficult to reach powerups. Unfortunately, this game lacks the assault game type which I found to be a lot of fun in UT'99, and the emphasis that UT3 places on the Warfare gametype during the campaign I found to be draining as the maps were just too large. I felt like I was playing Battlefield or something, with everyone flying or driving something accross a huge distance to complete some type of objective. But I digress. Basically what I'm trying to say that although this game has its merits and can stand on them, it's not as good or as fun to play as the games that preceeded it. It's a lot of fun and is good for LAN and online play and even though the graphics are amazing I think I'd still rather play UT'99. Your mileage may vary, however, and I'd still recommend this game as it's a fun shooter and is a member of a series that I think is at the front of the pack in the arena combat scene. Oh, and it comes with the UDK and Unreal Tournament 3 Editor and has great MOD support, so there's hours of fun outside of what comes in the box.Pros:Stunning VisualsTight GameplayGreat Music/AudioMOD SupportHas the Sniper Rifle! (Lightning Gun sucks.)Cons:A lot of focus on vehicular combatSome detrimental changes to UT gameplay and stylingGame felt more like a showroom for the Unreal 3 engine than a UT series gameNo Assault game typeSo-So Controller Support (I don't know what the "E" button is on my control pad)It's hard to enhance on near perfection and any changes you make to a beloved series is going to have some fallout and I appreciate the effort here. It wasn't a colossal failure like Diablo 3 was but it just didn't wow me like the previous UT games did. It was fun and it wasn't bad but if I'm playing some UT Deathmatch I'm probably not playing this game over the others. I'd say give it a shot and play it to see if it's your thing because the larger maps and new focus on vehicular combat may be something you enjoy a lot. Oh yeah, there also was a story (it didn't focus on the "tournament" though). I didn't really talk about it as it's not super important in a UT game but it was mediocre and had some cool moments. Good effort team, it certainly didn't detract anything from the game, I just didn't really care about it much. TL;DR nothing gets your heart pumping like Unreal Tournament - although it's not my favorite of the series it scratched an itch that hadn't been touched in years. B+

												Years and years of satisfaction with this one.I was addicted on the Unreal Tournament 99 GOTY, but when the Unreal Tournament 3 came out, I did nothing but playing it over and over again.Pros:Engine, obviously, the best FPS engine in my opinion.Game modes that can be really fun on single player mode too.Instant Action mode. Are you looking for some adrenaline and can't wait for the cutscenes and all the story of the game show up until you can finally shoot some heads off? That's your game mode then!The Bots are really fast if you want it. Very smart if you want it. They make you feel like a little baby trying to play the game if you want it! But they can be very stupid if you want it too. [There's a big variety of configurations that you can apply to the game before entering the action.]The graphics are very good. Not to argue about. And looks pretty modern even after so many years.Sound effects and music not so addictive like the UT99 ones, but close enough to make you feel fine.Cons:The Campaign looks boring if you don't like some of the game modes. But you can always go to the Instant Action mode. It gives the game the replay factor that every FPS should give.The Multiplayer mode is dead. (It's not because there are no people playing this game anymore, but Epic Games just has unplugged the servers after years and years of service. There are a mod somewhere that allows you to play in that mode if you want to search for it) But back in time, when you could play this mode, the number of custom servers with tons of custom maps and mods to download were so big that the wait until all the stuff to be downloaded and you finally enter the server was so absurd that you were disencouraged to play there anyway.It's a game that came out before the Steam, so there are more players with versions of the game out of here than the Steam players (but if you really want to play with friends in multiplayer mode, the mod that allow this, allows you to enjoy the game with all the people around the world too ;) )9/10

												Unreal Tournament 3 is a game in a very awkward position. On one hand, if you're a fan of the series, this game has probably stripped out some of your favorite features. On the other hand, if this is your first experience with an Unreal Tournament game, you might not immediately feel like UT3 is your kind of shooter. If you've never played an Unreal Tournament game, and you're looking for a fast-paced, competitive, well thought out, arena based shooter, this might be just the game for you. But, as many other reviews have shown, if you've played previous Unreal Tournament games, it might take some getting used to.UT3 is by no means the worst game ever made on the Unreal engine. Most fans of previous Unreal Tournament games are more than likely going to be a little disappointed with this sequel, most of them claiming the game was "dumbed down" or a "console port" and it is hard not to agree with them. However, just because it isn't what you expected doesn't mean you can't enjoy it for what it is.Let's start off by saying that while there is really no justification to buy a game based on aesthetics alone, UT3 is very pretty. Fans will say the graphics have been turned murky and brown, but the life and personality of previous Unreal games is very apparent in the visuals. Other shooter franchises don't put the kind of attention to detail into their levels that Unreal developers do. Every level has its own mood and unspoken narrative that make them a joy to just run around in.As far as other non-gameplay features are concerned, the soundtrack is yet another standout. The music in game is crafted in specific mood-setting parts that lend to the feel of the match at the time. When the game thinks it appropriate, it will switch up to another part of the song nearly seamlessly. So when you're capturing an enemy flag and the music turns into a more intense version of itself, you can actually notice the effect it has on your gameplay, raising your adrenaline and pushing you to perform better as the music pushes you on.On a macroscopic level, the formula for gameplay is relatively untouched from previous UT games. You pick up scattered weapons and powerups, you out-dodge and use your skills to snag big kill streaks, and when you inevitably die, you respawn in no more than 3 seconds, ready to jump right back in and do it again. If you were a fan of UT 2004's Onslaught mode, you'll be happy to know that it is back in a very polished form. The design of the vehicles within this mode is pretty stunning, and each one is very enjoyable to use. The same goes for every weapon. Since players have enough health to counter-attack, kills are satisfying and feel like an accomplishment in most cases, instead of a cheap shot on an enemy with no time to react.But, going a little deeper, fans will find that a few major gametypes have been lost in translation, including the very popular Assault gametype, in which players attack and defend a base with a linear string of objectives. Perhaps the developers thought that the new base warfare mode was too similar, and Assault was scrapped because of this. But you really shouldn't blow the game off just yet.Another odd feature is the frankly bizarre handling of campaign mode. Instead of the standard UT match-up ladder, the designers opted to make the campaign story based. Essentially, you fight a team of bots in a standard gametype, but there are story reasons for them. For example, you might be fighting in a deathmatch against a rival faction's mercenaries in an attempt to "drain their respawners". It feels very superficial to attempt to explain a tournament style game with a Gears of War style plot. Frankly, if you can ignore the plot, you'll likely enjoy the game more.Epic dropped the ball a little on supporting coop campaign mode. You have to restart Steam every time you or a friend playing with you quits campaign mode, which is more than a bit annoying. But as I soon discovered, playing through coop campaign mode with 2 or 3 friends against difficult bots is a total blast and a huge adrenaline pumping experience when your success as a team comes down to executing a plan between you perfectly. Every minor victory becomes a huge high when you were an essential part of it. This is the kind of feeling you just don't find often in coop shooters.So in the end, UT3 is a different kind of Unreal Tournament game. It was made to have mainstream console appeal, but it hasn't lost all which made its predecessors great. If you can ignore the frankly silly plot, overlook the minor missing features from previous games, and not get red in the face screaming about how much the main character looks like Marcus Fenix (and trust me, he does), then there is still a lot of fun to be had with UT3. My recommendation, buy a bundle of UT games during a sale and try to get the whole series, because you will likely pull hours, months, or maybe even years of enjoyment from each and every one.

												Back in 2007 Unreal Tournament 3 used to be what put 'Epic" in the "Epic Games". Explosive mixture of powerful weapons, lots of maps and vehicles with an amazing game pace as a topping. Perhaps the looks do not shine anymore as they did on game's release but for a 9 year old game it still looks extremely well. In regards to gameplay UT 3 is a nearly perfect experience. Starting from a wide choice of weapons most of them having secondary fire mode completely different from the basic one. Some of them even having a tretiary one. Lasers, bullets, plasma and rockets and a personal nuke launcher. This game has it all. Or rather used to have.Vast array of vehicles deserves similar recognition. Divided into two factions: Necris and Izanagi they offer unique approach both in design and function in each vehicle "class". Thus making them balanced while being much different in playstyle. Despite the fact that there were plenty maps on the game release there is an option to upload custom maps and mods to each server. There were also plenty of game modes avialable. From shooting classics like Team Deathmatch and Capture the Flag there is a twist of Vehicle Capture Flag and Warfare - the biggest game mode utilizing both infantry and vehicles to the full extent. Many of the maps including unique mechanics and side goals to aid defeat of the enemy. As if things weren't exciting enough already every game mode possesed mutators allowing to differ the gameplay even further. All of the above got a finishing touch in 2009's Titan Pack update adding content unreleased in base game as well as classic game modes - Greed and Betrayal.This heavily mutiplayer-oriented title comes with a really long campaign although it's basically a series of bot matches with a pinch of lore divided into 5 acts. Each finished with a nice cinematic. Single is a good opportunity to get a feel of map roster before leaping into mutiplayer but nothing else. Unless played on highest diffculty - bots there are barely fair forcing the player to push their skill to the limits.For such a gem it's somewhat sad how empty the game is today. This is the reason why I would only reccomend the Unreal Tournament 3 to the franchise fans - there is simply hardly anyone left to play with. Meaning you will either face bots (even in few mutiplayer servers left) or battle-hardned veterans. It's nice to experience the ridiculous pace of the game that is hardly matched by any modern title. But it is a nostalgic memory that along with UT 3 belongs in the past.

												I really wanted to like this game, but it's cons unfortunately outweigh the pros; it's impossible to find an unmodded game online, there is a lack of characters and levels, and the campaign is a massive waste of time. They also didn't include the beloved "Assault" game mode. The campaign's story is remarkably boring, and the worst part is they force you to play the ridiculous "Onslaught" levels which is a gimmicky mode in the first place, and the bot's AI is completely unreliable, making it almost impossible for me to progress on higher difficulties simply because my bots were not doing their jobs.In the original Unreal Tournament, playing the single player was fun because you could choose whichever game mode you felt like playing and work your way up the ladder, getting familiar with every single level so when you go online you're ready. There is a sense of completion as you go for nothing more than tournament glory. But in Unreal Tournament III you have to slog through a terrible and cliche story that isn't related to any tournament at all and you aren't given any choice which modes you want to train in. Even more frustrating is that the online mode is almost entirely unsupported. You have no stats, no functional matchmaking, and it's impossible to get you and your friends into the same game. They completely dropped the ball here. Other than that, the original core game is actually really fun. It's got that dark gritty Unreal feel, and it's super-gory so it's really satisfying when you get a kill. The best game mode is Deathmatch because it's the only one that actually represents what the game is supposed to be about in the first place: gladiatorial arena killing. But instead of adding the "Assault" game mode or supporting the "Team Deathmatch" and "Capture The Flag" modes with functional match-making, they did nothing here and just kept the "Onslaught" mode with the ridiculous vehicle combat that doesn't even feel like a tournament fighter anymore. It's just some vehicle gimmick they added ever since Halo came out.Just skip this one. The original Unreal Tournament is better in every single way except for the graphics, which are the only good thing I can say about this game. Don't get me wrong -- it's extremely fun to play for ten or fifteen minutes if you just want to kill some bots when you're bored, but beyond that I can say with confidence that this game offers nothing else worthwhile.

												Epic released a statistic that said 70% of the people who bought Unreal Tournament 2004 never played it online. Given how often I played offline with bots, I'd believe that. Unfortunately, UT3 introduces a laughably stupid singleplayer campaign that is more repetitive than it is fun or interesting. By trying to make a legitimate "story mode" for the game, they've sort of spoiled the fun of the original, because there's a lot of story stuff that gets in the way. There's still ways to do regular bot skirmishes, though, so it's not such a big problem.What is a big problem is that it's just not especially fun to play. The smaller maps feel too cramped and the larger maps get to be a little too large. Onslaught mode from UT2004 has been remade here as a retooled "Warfare" mode, and it's been changed for the worst. Players can now carry an orb around that lets them capture control points instantly without waiting, but instead of speeding the game up, all it does is make long, drawn out, tedious stalemates the norm, as teams fight over one or two nodes and instantly revert any progress made by the opposing team, over and over and over again. I've had Warfare matches go on for hours without much progress from either side, and enabling a time limit for rounds does little to alleviate the issue, as sudden death doesn't really mean anything when neither team's core is ever exposed.Plus, the guns just don't feel good. They feel meaty, sure, but something about them is... "off" in a way that's hard to describe.All this really made me do was re-install UT2004 and play that instead.

												Another game I hate to see fall, Its a fun game but at the end of the day once you look at it after all of the hype has come to an end, its not that great. I really want to like this game, but I just can't. And I can't stand the blind Unreal Tournament fanbase saying that this is the best Unreal of all time, when in reality its probably one of the worst. To sum it all up, its a first person shooter multiplayer version of Gears of War (In my opinion one of the most overrated video game series in gaming) Unreal Tournament 3 is fun, don't get me wrong, but compared to Unreal Tournament 2003/2004 or the first Unreal Tournament, its no comparison. The single player is mixed bag, at times its great fun and addicting, and at other times is just frustrating. I really appreciate the attempt to add a story to the campaign, but this is also again where it falls flat. They tried to give you options on which battle you choose and said it would impact how you played the next match and they also added something called player cards you can collect to even or add an advantage, almost like an RPG. However choosing a certain battle over another never seem to do anything of importance in the next match, and the player cards to me are stupid addition. The whole point of the arena FPS was so everyone was on an even playing field and the fact that you need player cards to make the battle even or that can give yourself an advantage, goes against everything the Arena FPS stood for, an even playing field. But after all that it begins to get very repetative, the graphics are what most people complain about because they have a strange tinge of Brown in every map (even in cave and ice themed maps) and I can't believe no one has criticized the AI, THE AI IS ♥♥♥♥ING BRAIN DEAD!!!!! Why does Epic insist on using the same AI from 1999? and why do the Unreal Tournament fans choose to turn a blind eye to it every time? The AI are by far the most frustrating part of the whole game, Especially the friendly AI, because you can't give them orders, there were so many times in Vehicle CTF or Warfare maps when allies would pile into a Leviathan, (for those that don't know, has a very powerful secondary cannon on it, but to use it you have to anchor it to the ground and so it can't move) They will pile into it and just sit there and fire at enemies, leaving you and 1 other friendly AI to complete the whole mission, which is impossible since the other team have more players, because you don't have a player card to even the teams. My advice to Epic in the future Unreal Tournament games is simple, FIX THE DAMN AI!!!! Another strange addition is the Ord in Warfare. (What it does is, it capture nods instantly, and if you stand next to a already captured nod, it protects it from damage or capture) Now sometimes it works very well especially on maps with secondary points that hold a certain purpose, like the countdown nod in the mine map, that does damage to the enemy core without them needing to be linked or ones that can create heavy vehicles giving you a stronger push, however on other maps its frustrating and just makes some games go longer than they really need to.Multiplayer is also a mixed bag as well, at times its great, but most of the times its frustrating. This really pisses me off more than anything, because Unreal Tournament is known for its multiplayer, and in this game the single player campaign is more fun than playing multiplayer. Most of the multiplayer fanbase is populated by Unreal Tournament veterans, that essentially wipe the floor with all new players. Not to mention, finding a match in general is frustrating, sometimes you will look for a server and it says that it has 11/32 players on it, but when you finally get to play after it takes 10 minutes to load all of the stupid mods, you find that its completely populated by bots, and you completely wasted your time. The Shock Rifle is probably the worst weapon by far, for those that don't know you can fire the secondary fire, then shoot the ord you just fired with primary and it creates an huge explosion, this has been in unreal since the beginning, however in Unreal Tournament 3 the explosion is ever bigger than before, so now you die so easily, even if you have max armor and health, its even worse on small confined maps, most of the time you die from behind.At the end of the day Unreal Tournament 3 is not the best Epic could do, I hope that in the future Unreal Tournament games these problems do not persist, because Unreal is a great franchise. But in my opinion this game is not worth 19 dollars, don't buy this game unless you are an unreal addict

They decided to nerf them, sure there's blood and gore, but I believe there are mods to revamp damage to "exposive" levels again.Thirdly, the A.I. is bull. Now before you ask specifics, lemme explain. 												I want to like this game, I really do, but I just can't.Having bought this game 3 times now (PS3, PC collectors' ed. and now Steam) and playing well over 100 hours across, as an arena shooter this game has some things going for it, but as a UT sequel and in light of the plethora of good team-arena shooters out there falls painfully short. First of all, one staple objective-driven gametype (assault) and another innovative football-like gametype introduced in UT2K4 (bombing run) have been axed entirely. Warfare (formerly onslaught) has undergone a number of questionable design choices (insta-capture orbs) which altar game flow dramatically. Many of the movement options which made UT2K4 a hit with the competitive scence as well as 'adrenaline' combos (admittedly a controversial addition in the first place) are no longer.However perhaps the most glaring design failure was the direction Epic decided to steer this game. Hot on the heels of Gears of Wars' success and with plenty of unused art assets, Epic tossed out the Tournament canon in favor of an extremely lackluster filler campaign akin to those that ship with the yearly COD releases. Furthermore, many prominent and loved tourney combatants were either removed or attached to an unrecognizable body. Graphically these bodies have been disfigured and hyper-muscularized and the lush arenas of previous titles have been tossed out in favor of the muddy, bloom and postprocessing-heavy urban jungles so characteristic of its generation. It's also worth noting that unlike its namesake, this game came out on console first and shipped to PC with a (since partially fixed) console UI. This disrespect for canon and shoddy presentation make clear one thing: on release, Epic simply valued money over their fan base.Sure, Epic didn't completely abandon the title, to their credit releasing several solid maps, patches and the Titan bonus pack, as well as sponsoring tournaments and the Make Something Unreal contest, but it was still only a band-aid over the aforementioned lacerating flaws of this title. Note that this support (long-since ended) came and went 3-years-ago, the community having dwindled to, at the time of this writing, one-to-three scantly populated servers per game mode (compared to 10-20 near-capacity in UT99/UT2K4).Did Epic release a few interesting new features for this game? Sure, the hoverboard/grapple is invaluable over larger maps and Warfare's bonus nodes bring variety to the mode; several of the new maps are also well-designed. However, it's a big loss compared to what you are giving up from the previous titles and I'd recommend that if you're into the larger-scale or competitive aspects look into UT2K4, quake-like team-arena modes UT99. Viewed apart from the series, it's a mediocre team-arena shooter with a weak community, and even Tribes: Ascend will serve you better.ANOTHER IMPORTANT NOTE: If you do own a retail PC copy of UT3, you can save yourself the expense and redeem the key for a free Steam copy.

												The Black Edition of Unreal Tournament 3 adds much needed new maps and gamemodes to add more content and is the definitive version of Unreal Tournament 3. UT3 is often forgotten and when it's not, people criticize it as being the worst Unreal Tournament game. Well, they're right. The games campaign is absolutely atrocious. Instead of the idea of the tournaments like in the other games and the managing that made UT2K4's single-player tournament ladder so fun, we instead have an actual story in which there's a war between the Necris and humans or something like that. It's absolutely forgettable and the way it tries to tie itself into the idea of respawning and doing things like Capture the Flag in a fully fledged war is just hilarious. It also features surprisingly atrocious acting (not exaggerating) and some of the worst writing I've seen in a game. The Unreal Tournament games had cheesy dialogue on purpose but when this takes itself so seriously it's just really hard to watch. The main issue with the game however is how heavy and weighty the movement is in this game. UT'99 and UT2K4 had fluid movement, which was needed for a fast paced arena game, but this along with muddy, bland graphics just makes it a game to skip and absolutely unnecessary when there are two far superior games and an incredible single-player focussed game, the original Unreal.Pros:+Music features some nice reinditions of UT99 classics+Sound effects are meaty, very well done+Fantastic particle effects+Vast amount of graphical setting options+Weapon array is nice as usual+Character customization is neat+Good atmosphere+New vehicles are awesome+Vehicles handle well+Onslaught is much improved from UT2K4'sCons:-Voice-acting goes beyond cheesy-Campaign should be skipped-Though music is good, there's a lack of new stuff-Graphics are bland and ugly despite having decent textures-Heavy feeling movement is a big negative in a game like this-Controller support leaves more to be desired-Less maps and gamemodes than the UT'99 and UT2K4-Characters all look big bulky and generic and aren't faithful to original designs-AI still hasn't been all that improved-Less mutators-No tournament style campaign like UT2K4-No people playing...never wereSound: 8/10Graphics: 4.5/10 Gameplay: 7/10Content/Replayability: 7/10Overall: 5.5/10I recommend UT3 if you're going to play as on easier difficulties to just mince some people, but there's no use spending time to relearn mechanics to play on harder difficulties if you played the others. Just skip it. Worse in most ways to its predecessors.

er 10, 2014
												Of all of the UT games made after 99, this might be the least bad.The gameplay is sub par, but it is a lot easier to get 10 people to download UT 3 off steam than it is to hand out UT99 CDs.  Actually that's not true; we had a bunch of authentication problems playing UT 3 on a LAN even though we all purchased it.The game DOES have a sniper rifle, and does NOT have that stupid ♥♥♥ lightning gun, so that's a huge plus.The rocket launcher's alternate fire only fires 3 rockets.  The only weapon with a lamer alt fire is the bio rifle.There are some classic maps which cool improvements, like Deck 17 and Facing Worlds.The single player campain is incredibly annoying.  Plotwise, they try to sort of invent this unecessary, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ story backwards from deathmatch to explain people dying and respawning all the time.  It seems complately unrelated to the "plot" of UT99.  The worst, though, is that you can't choose to play only deathmatch levels and/or completely ignore certain game modes.For multiplayer, they also try to force you onto some lame social media thing (which does not connect to steam) in order to play with other people.  I wish I had known that before buying.  At the last lan party I attended, no one was able to connect this way, so we all opted to play in disconnected/offline mode or whatever they call it.  Unfortunately when you do that, there is no UI for changing your name; you have to open the console and type something every single time you join.  Also, so far, I haven't found a way to save your single player progress in offline mode.A lot of very simple configurations and settings that I took for granted have been removed.  For example:  you can't do random map rotations.  UT 99 had a simple checkbox that let you enable map rotation to avoid playing the same order every time, or disable for people who hate fun.  It does seem like they've opted to have "mutators" take the place of simple configuration options, and I don't have a strong opinion on that, but they didn't include a mutator to put the random map feature back.The bot skill levels are a little wacky.  "Skilled" level bots spend a lot of time standing in one place waiting to be shot.  That seems like something that maybe only the first bot level should do.There is some new war mode thing with spheres.  Its kind of cool, although the vehicles are pretty lame.  Especially the hover board.  And Assault is gone.

												This is Multiplayer shooting at it's very finest.I've been an Unreal Tournament fan since around the same time that I learned to walk. I remember playing (massively underage) with my Dad back in 1999 and both of us continutally getting stuck on the championship phase. On and off I've played the games for the best part of 20 years and this shows little sign of slowing down.So I guess it's easy to say  that this game has something of a personal resonance with me. I have incredibly good memories of blasting enemies away for days on end and will defend the game zealously. But don't let my bias fool you, see for yourself and experiance those older games.I remember buying UT3 many years ago and although I loved it, it sort of slipped under the radar for me. This was back in one of my console stretches, so I guess I thought "This is nice, but let's play Halo!" However, with announcement of a new UT on the horizon, I felt it only right to attempt to fully re-discover it. After jogging my memory of happy console hours shooting my brother and friends, I have discovered the true beauty of UT3.The fact that the game is the product of 20 years of TLC from both Epic and the UNREAL community is instantly noticable. It's unbelievably  sleak design of weapons and maps (I guess) could be a slap in the face to a gamer used to Call of Duty and Battlefield, but it is a beautiful and welcoming slap. One that's soreness quickly disappears in place of pleasure. In moments, your eyes scan the beautiful battlefield and the ease of player movement make you feel like a seasoned warrior suiting up and dealing death .If the design and beauty of the game wasn't enough, the accessibility  will draw you in. Unlike it's unforgiving and esoteric cousin QUAKE, UT has always been a welcoming experiance. The bots provide ample challenge (should you wish) in lieu of online players and the wide variety of game-modes are all unsurpassed in their polish. It does reward the twitch reaction and headshot with certain weapons, but UT3 encourages guile and planning too, yielding a unique playstyle that is both intricate and rampant.So here is a game that is both challenging and brilliantly fun. It is a tonic to the disturbing modern trend of skill-less, lumbering shooting in multiplayer and shows that the 90s/00s formula of the arena game is not only still relevant, but can lead to innovation and great enjoyment.Buy, love and enjoy. Roll on the next UT.

												I've been a fan of the Unreal series since the original Unreal, but i find UT3 to be the most disappointing of them all (yes, i liked Unreal 2 more).I hate how consolized the menu is, i hate how Epic tried to pander to the Gears of War fans with those bulky and incredibly ugly player models that all look the same, i hate how all the maps have been "modernized" by removing colors and making everything grey & bloom, and i hate how they scrapped the single player tournament, a feature which i personally loved especially after how awesome and interactive they made it in UT2004, and replaced it with a generic war story i could have found in any other action game.However, UT3 has a redeeming factor: the modding. Just like in the previous games, you can download new and interesting player models made by the community, or even some older ones from the previous games. As always you can download hundreds of interesting maps ranging from the silly ones and giant rooms to classic remakes to the more impressive well-done maps. Mutators and total conversions are also still available, my favourite one being The Crucible, although many good ones from the past like ChaosUT and Ballistic unfortunately didn't go beyond demo stages.To top it all off, you can replace the whole menu with one worthy of a PC game by using the MapMixer mod. I especially like how it also lets you "clone" bots to customize and rename them, a feature which hasn't been around since UT99. If you're like me and still hold a grudge on the art style direction they took with UT3, the ability to block off GoW bots and default maps from ever being played is also quite nice.I can't say anything about the online aspect because i haven't been able to find any servers, possibly due to my game's settings not wanting to work.All in all i still recommend this game to UT fans, but only if you're planning to download custom content for it. And if you're not a UT fan, i suggest checking out UT99 and UT2004 first.

												Wow... What a game this is! I sorely misunderstood it's strengths and underestimated this game for years. I've always tried to play through the single player campaign and always bounced right off it as that mode is genuinely terrible, repetitive and boring. However as I'll go onto explain, this was a mistake.Firstly, the reason for not enjoying the campaign mode is due to it focusing on the "Capture the Flag" and "Warfare" team modes. Capture the Flag (CTF) is a familair game type and Warfare is about Capturing Control Points which includes vehicles you can use to fight your battles along with the usual weapons. Warfare matches in particular are normally set on huge sprawling battle fields for it to take place across... so why is this terrible?It boils down to the Bot AI specifically for Warfare (CTF isn't too bad to be fair)... simple as that. They cannot play this team mode in any fun way and these long.. drawn out...  tug of war matches get mired in stalemate and boredom. There are only so many times you can spend minutes trekking across a huge map to be killed pointlessly and then respawn to do it again. With human teams, working together to co-ordinate attack and defence, I imagine it would be great... but the bots know nothing of a high strategy and the game degenerates into pockets of combat that just chew up and spit everyone out resulting in a grind. No flanking, feints, different paths of attack or even retreating, just running at each other, fighting, dying and doing it again which is ultimately what the player is drawn into as well. Awful...  and so UT3 was in my view the worst game of the series... UNTIL! I ignored the campaign mode and just worked through every available map via the Instant Action option (i.e. Custom Match Mode), sticking to the game types I enjoyed. Playing like this is BRILLIANT...  I played Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Greed ( a form of deathmatch CTF) and Instagib deathmatch (one hit kills) all on Adept difficulty and just ignored the other modes I didn't like or just weren't enjoyable to play with bots... and man alive what a game!The speed, the sound, the graphics, the weapons..  adept diffculty was the exact amount of challenge for me at the time of writing. Every match was an unknown and I never went into a game confident I'd win or sure I'd lose. UT3 is on par with the mighty UT 1999 (IMHO) when it comes to playing with bots on the main Deathmatch modes. It is great!I ended up playing 145 matches across those 4 modes on every map to eventually win them all, and that doesn't include the games I played on the campaign in co-op with Steam friends, or the experiments with some of the other modes like Betrayal or CTF. Truely an excellent game when you stick to it's strengths and I enjoyed "completing" the game per my own rules for doing so. I think making my own objectives within some games is going to breathe new life into them where I have stopped playing due to a lack of direction from the game or a terrible single player story / campaign mode. It's not something I have done before... as silly as that sounds, and I am glad I did here as it opened my eyes to an excellent game.Although I have completed my "Adept" run, I'll be trying again on harder difficulties and downloading user maps for sure. This game will likely stay on my hard drive for a long time and the "time played" (currently 35hrs) will increase beyond what is recorded here, just like UT 1999.
